summary_points: 1. On April 29, 2025, Constellation Brands issued $500 million in 4.800% Senior Notes due 2030, with the proceeds intended for general corporate purposes including debt repayment.
2. The public offering price of the notes was 99.824% of the principal amount.
3.  The purchase of the notes by underwriters is scheduled to close on May 1, 2025, subject to customary closing conditions.

1. Smurfit Westrock plc announced on April 30, 2025, the permanent closure of its coated recycled board mill in St. Paul, Minnesota, and its containerboard mill in Forney, Texas, as well as two converting facilities in Germany, impacting approximately 650 employees.
2.  The company anticipates incurring approximately $99 million in pre-tax cash charges and $188 million in pre-tax non-cash asset impairment charges related to these closures.
3. The $226 million of charges will be recognized in the second quarter of 2025, with the remaining $61 million expected to be recognized through the rest of 2025 and into 2026.
1. FMC Corp's Q1 2025 revenue was $791 million, a 14% decrease year-over-year (10% organically), primarily due to a 9% price decline and lower volumes.
2.  FMC Corp's Q1 2025 adjusted EBITDA was $120 million, a 25% decrease year-over-year.

3.  FMC Corp maintains its full-year 2025 revenue guidance of $4.15 billion to $4.35 billion, but anticipates incremental tariff costs of $15 million to $20 million, which it plans to offset with cost savings and volume increases.
1. Aflac's Q1 2025 net earnings plummeted to $29 million, a dramatic 98.5% decrease from $1.9 billion in Q1 2024, primarily due to significant net investment losses.
2. Total revenues fell by $2 billion (37.5%) year-over-year in Q1 2025, reaching $3.4 billion.
3. Despite the significant revenue and profit decline, Aflac repurchased $900 million in shares and plans to increase dividends in Q1 2025.
1. Conagra Brands, Inc. amended its Term Loan Agreement with Bank of America, extending the maturity date of a $300 million unsecured term loan to October 29, 2025.
2. Conagra Brands, Inc. entered into a new Term Loan Agreement with Mizuho Bank, Ltd. for $200 million in unsecured term loans, also maturing on October 29, 2025.

3. The Mizuho Term Loan Agreement includes financial covenants requiring Conagra to maintain a maximum net leverage ratio and a minimum interest coverage ratio; failure to meet these could trigger default and immediate repayment.
1. Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc. lowered its full-year 2025 comparable hotel total RevPAR growth guidance to 0.7% to 2.7%, down from the previous forecast of 1.0% to 3.0% due to slower group bookings.
2. As of March 31, 2025, the company's debt-to-asset ratio was 39.5%.
3. First-quarter 2025 comparable hotel RevPAR increased by 7.0%, while comparable hotel total RevPAR increased by 5.8%.
1. Jack Henry & Associates, Inc. reported deconversion revenue of $9.6 million for the fiscal third quarter ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Full-year fiscal 2025 deconversion revenue guidance has been updated to a range of $22 million to $28 million.
3.  Deconversion revenue is excluded from non-GAAP revenue as it is generated from factors outside of Jack Henry's control and does not represent the ongoing business operations.

1. Ventas, Inc. amended its Revolving Credit Agreement on April 29, 2025, increasing its revolving commitments from $2.75 billion to $3.5 billion, with an option to increase this further to $4.5 billion.
2.  Ventas, Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 results (as of March 31, 2025) show Normalized Funds From Operations (Normalized FFO) per share increased by approximately 8% year-over-year to $0.84.

3.  Ventas, Inc. increased its 2025 guidance for senior housing investment volume to $1.5 billion (from $1 billion), primarily funded by existing unsettled forward equity commitments and disposition proceeds.
1. ANSYS's Q1 2025 net income increased significantly year-over-year, rising by 47.5% (GAAP) to $51,865,000.
2.  ANSYS's Q1 2025 revenue grew by 8.2% year-over-year, reaching $504,891,000.
3.  As of April 30, 2025, ANSYS faces potential liabilities of $7.2 million from an ongoing Indian service tax audit, and the outcome of its proposed merger with Synopsys remains uncertain.
1. C.H. Robinson Worldwide, Inc. reported a 39.1% year-over-year increase in income from operations for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, reaching $176.9 million.
2. Total revenues decreased by 8.3% year-over-year to $4.0 billion in Q1 2025, primarily due to the divestiture of the Europe Surface Transportation business.
3.  C.H. Robinson projects capital expenditures between $65 million and $75 million for the full year 2025.
1. Ansys, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $504.9 million, an 8% increase in reported currency and a 10% increase in constant currency compared to the first quarter of 2024.
2.  First-quarter 2025 diluted earnings per share were $0.59 on a GAAP basis and $1.64 on a non-GAAP basis, compared to $0.40 and $1.39 respectively for the first quarter of 2024.

3. As of April 30, 2025, the acquisition of Ansys by Synopsys is anticipated to close in the first half of 2025, subject to regulatory approvals and other closing conditions;  Ansys has suspended quarterly earnings conference calls and no longer provides guidance due to the pending acquisition.
1. Stanley Black & Decker's net sales decreased by 3% year-over-year to $3.745 billion in Q1 2025, primarily due to currency exchange rates and the sale of its Infrastructure business.
2.  The company's Q1 2025 effective tax rate was 29.2%, significantly lower than the 59.6% rate in Q1 2024.
3.  Stanley Black & Decker anticipates further charges and cash investments beyond 2025 for its supply chain transformation.
1. On April 28, 2025, Christopher Kubasik, L3Harris Technologies' CEO, implemented a 10b5-1 plan to sell up to 147,411 shares of company stock between July and September 9, 2025.
2.  The plan covers options granted in 2017 and expiring in 2027.
3.  The sales will be publicly disclosed via Form 4 and Form 144 filings.
1. American Water Works Company, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 earnings per share of $1.05, a $0.10 increase compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, the company affirmed its 2025 earnings per share guidance range of $5.65 to $5.75 and its long-term EPS and dividend growth rate targets of 7-9%.

3. The company's increased operating revenues in Q1 2025 were primarily due to new rates resulting from capital and acquisition investments, but were offset by higher operating costs, depreciation, and financing costs.
1. D. Adamczyk retired from Johnson & Johnson's Board of Directors on May 31, 2025, to join Goldman Sachs as a Partner.

2.  At the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, the shareholder proposal for shareholder opportunity to vote on excessive golden parachutes was rejected, with 1,609,744,641 shares against and only 92,601,525 shares for.

3. A shareholder proposal to produce a human rights impact assessment was also rejected at the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders; 1,498,659,169 shares voted against the proposal compared to 188,350,832 shares in favour.
1. PSEG Power's Q1 2025 net income was negatively impacted by $135 million in after-tax losses from non-trading commodity mark-to-market activity.
2. PSEG's net assets measured at fair value decreased by $300 million between March 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025.
3.  The LIPA board's rejection of a recommendation to renew PSEG Long Island's operations services agreement, expiring December 31, 2025, creates significant uncertainty.
1. On April 30, 2025, Philip Morris International Inc. issued $2,500,000,000 in notes with maturities ranging from 2028 to 2035,  at various interest rates.
2.  The issuance of these notes comprised Floating Rate Notes ($400,000,000), 4.125% Notes due 2028 ($750,000,000), 4.375% Notes due 2030 ($750,000,000), and 4.875% Notes due 2035 ($600,000,000).
3. Philip Morris intends to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes, repaying commercial paper, refinancing existing 3.375% Notes due 2025, or meeting working capital requirements.
1. American Water plans to invest $3.3 billion in infrastructure, acquisitions, and growth in 2025.
2. Diluted earnings per share increased by $0.10 to $1.05 in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024.
3.  American Water completed two acquisitions adding 1,850 customers and has agreements for two more adding 10,200 customers as of April 30, 2025.
1. Discover's Q1 2025 net income increased by 30% year-over-year to $1.1 billion.
2.  The merger with Capital One is expected to close around May 18, 2025, having received all necessary regulatory approvals by April 18, 2025.
3. Discover incurred $250 million in total penalties from the Federal Reserve and FDIC related to card product misclassification, with $1.2 billion in related liabilities as of March 31, 2025.

1. Keurig Dr Pepper Inc. issued $2 billion in senior notes on April 28, 2025, with an expected net proceeds of approximately $1.986 billion after expenses, to be used for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment.

2. The notes offering included four tranches: $500 million of floating rate senior notes due 2026, and $500 million each of 4.350%, 4.600%, and 5.150% senior notes due 2028, 2030, and 2035, respectively.
3. The closing of the notes offering is expected to occur on May 5, 2025, subject to customary closing conditions.
1. On April 30, 2025, Cooper Companies, Inc. expanded its Board of Directors from seven to eight members, appointing Barbara Carbone as an independent director, effective May 1, 2025.
2.  Ms. Carbone's appointment to the Audit Committee is concurrent with her appointment to the Board.
3. Ms. Carbone's director compensation will align with that of other non-employee directors, as detailed in the company's February 19, 2025 proxy statement.
1. ONEOK's year-over-year revenue increased by $3,262 million in the three months ended March 31, 2025, primarily due to acquisitions.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, ONEOK projects 2025 capital expenditures between $2.8 and $3.2 billion, despite recently announced federal tariffs.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, ONEOK had $200 million in commercial paper outstanding and used a joint venture with MPLX to temporarily avoid a decrease in their leverage ratio covenant.
1. MGM Resorts International's Q1 2025 net income decreased by 31.6% year-over-year to $148,554,000.
2.  MGM China refinanced its debt in April 2025, securing a new HK$23.4 billion senior unsecured revolving credit facility maturing in April 2030.

3.  MGM Resorts International is committed to investing up to approximately $2.6 billion in the Osaka IR KK project over the next four years, although the actual amount and timing remain subject to change.
1. Equity Residential's (EQR) diluted earnings per share/unit decreased from $0.77 to $0.67 between Q1 2024 and Q1 2025.
2. EQR's universal shelf registration statement, crucial for future capital raising, expires in May 2025.
3. EQR faces multiple lawsuits alleging antitrust violations related to rent pricing, with an uncertain outcome.
1. Invitation Homes Operating Partnership LP amended its Term Loan Agreement on April 28, 2025, changing the maturity date from June 22, 2029, to April 28, 2028, with two 12-month extension options.
2.  The margin on borrowings under the amended Credit Agreement, effective April 28, 2025, ranges from 0.00% to 0.60% for base rate loans and 0.75% to 1.60% for Term SOFR loans.

3. Three lenders (First Financial Bank, Raymond James Bank, and Land Bank of Taiwan, New York Branch) departed from the Term Loan Agreement on April 28, 2025, resulting in a reallocation of the loans among the remaining lenders.
1. Essex Property Trust's net income decreased by $69.62 million (25.5%) in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024, resulting in diluted earnings per share of $3.16, down from $4.25.
2.  Same-property revenues increased by 3.4% year-over-year in Q1 2025, driven primarily by a 2.1% rise in average rental rates.
3.  The company anticipates recognizing $210,000 (70% of $300,000) of its remaining performance obligations after 2025, extending into 2027.
1. UDR, Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 Same-Store Net Operating Income (NOI) grew 2.8% year-over-year, exceeding expectations.
2.  UDR, Inc. is searching for a new CFO.
3. As of April 30, 2025, UDR, Inc. has $5.8 billion in total indebtedness, with a relatively small portion (9.7%) maturing before 2027.
1. Crown Castle sold its Fiber Business for $8.5 billion on April 30, 2025, resulting in its presentation as discontinued operations.
2. Despite 5% organic growth in tower site rental revenues (excluding Sprint cancellations), overall Q1 2025 revenues declined by 5.3% compared to Q1 2024.
3.  The company plans to reduce its annualized dividend per share to $4.25 in Q2 2025.

1. Everest Group, Ltd. reported a net income of $210 million and net operating income of $276 million for the first quarter of 2025, significantly lower than the $733 million and $709 million reported in Q1 2024, respectively.

2.  The company's combined ratio was 102.7% in Q1 2025, compared to 88.8% in Q1 2024; this increase is primarily attributed to $472 million in pre-tax catastrophe losses (net of recoveries and reinstatement premiums) in Q1 2025, versus $85 million in the same period last year.
3. Everest anticipates completing its U.S. casualty remediation later in 2025.
1. Meta Platforms, Inc. reported a 35% year-over-year increase in net income for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, reaching $16.64 billion.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Meta had $70.23 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities.

3. The European Commission's decision that Meta's ad-free subscription model is non-compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) could materially negatively impact its European business and revenue as early as the third quarter of 2025.
1. As of March 31, 2025, Invitation Homes Inc. had $1,364 million in available liquidity and total indebtedness of $8,184 million, with 87.5% of total debt fixed rate or swapped to fixed rate.
2. Year-over-year for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, total revenues increased by 4.4% to $674 million, while net income available to common stockholders increased by 16.4% to $166 million.

3.  Invitation Homes Inc. amended its $725 million term loan, extending the maturity date to April 2030 and lowering the interest rate by 40 basis points (to SOFR plus 85 basis points), effective April 28, 2025.

1. Timothy J. Aydt, Executive Vice President, Refining, retired from Marathon Petroleum Corporation on September 2, 2025, after over 40 years of service; Mike Henschen will succeed him on June 1, 2025.
2.  The filing is an 8-K, indicating a current report, filed on April 30, 2025.
3. Mr. Aydt will assist with the transition in a non-executive officer role until his retirement.
1. MGM Resorts International announced a new $2 billion stock repurchase plan on April 30, 2025, in addition to an existing plan.
2.  First-quarter 2025 consolidated net revenues decreased by 2% year-over-year to $4.3 billion, primarily due to lower revenues at Las Vegas Strip Resorts and MGM China.
3.  The company expects to exceed $150 million in EBITDA enhancements in 2025, stemming from a $200 million initiative launched in 2024.
1. Abbott Laboratories' net sales increased by 4% year-over-year to $10.36 billion in the first quarter of 2025 (excluding foreign exchange impacts).
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Abbott had $6.123 billion in total remaining performance obligations across its Diagnostic and Medical Devices segments.

3. Abbott is contesting potential $1.052 billion in additional tax assessments from the IRS and is involved in ongoing litigation related to its infant formula, including a $495 million jury award currently under appeal.
1. Equinix's net income increased significantly year-over-year, rising from $231 million in Q1 2024 to $343 million in Q1 2025.
2. Adaire Fox-Martin will become CEO and President of Equinix in 2025, with Charles Meyers transitioning to Executive Chairman until the 2026 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.
3.  Equinix has $11.3 billion in remaining performance obligations as of March 31, 2025, with 65% expected to be recognized as revenue within the next two years.
1. Equinix, Inc. reported Q1 2025 revenues of $2.2 billion, a 5% increase year-over-year (as-reported) or 8% on a normalized and constant currency basis.
2.  Equinix raised its full-year 2025 revenue guidance by $142 million to a range of $9.175 - $9.275 billion, primarily due to a $135 million favorable foreign currency impact.
3.  The company has 56 major data center projects underway, including 12 xScale projects, to meet growing demand for AI and cloud services.
1. Pool Corporation increased its share repurchase program by $309.2 million to a total of $600 million as of April 29, 2025.
2.  The company declared a 4% increase in its quarterly cash dividend to $1.25 per share, payable May 29, 2025, to stockholders of record on May 15, 2025.

3.  At the April 30, 2025, annual stockholder meeting, there were significant variations in votes for the reelection of individual directors, with David G. Whalen receiving substantially fewer "For" votes (29,360,676) than others (over 32 million).
1. Fiserv, Inc. and its subsidiary, Fiserv Funding, issued €2,175,000,000 in senior notes due between 2028 and 2036 in a public offering expected to close on May 7, 2025.
2. The offering included €750,000,000 of 2.875% Senior Notes due 2028, €775,000,000 of 3.500% Senior Notes due 2032, and €650,000,000 of 4.000% Senior Notes due 2036.
3.  The Underwriting Agreement, filed as Exhibit 1.1, contains customary representations, warranties, conditions to closing, indemnification rights, and termination provisions.

1. At the 2025 Annual Meeting held on April 25, 2025, Stanley Black & Decker shareholders elected nine directors and approved, on an advisory basis, executive compensation and the selection of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for the 2025 fiscal year.

2.  While all director nominees were elected, the "against" votes ranged from 796,050 to 5,424,106 shares, representing a significant level of opposition to some candidates compared to the approximately 120 million votes "for".

3.  Proposal 2, concerning executive compensation, received only 99,520,434 "for" votes out of a possible 154,537,524, indicating a substantial portion of shareholders either voted "against" or abstained.
1. VICI Properties' allowance for credit losses increased by $80 million in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024, primarily due to increased tenant default probability.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, VICI Properties has committed a total of $510 million towards the $725 million North Fork Mono Casino & Resort development.
3. VICI Properties made a $300 million mezzanine loan investment in the One Beverly Hills development on February 19, 2025.
1. Microsoft's Microsoft Cloud revenue grew 20% year-over-year to $42.4 billion in Q3 2025.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Microsoft faces potential total legal liabilities of $1.33 billion.
3. The IRS is seeking an additional $28.9 billion in tax payments from Microsoft for tax years 2004-2013.
1. KLA Corporation announced a new $5 billion share repurchase program on April 30, 2025, in addition to an existing program with approximately $457 million remaining.
2.  For the third quarter of fiscal year 2025 (ended March 31, 2025), KLA reported total revenues of $3.06 billion, exceeding the midpoint of its guidance range.

3.  KLA's guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2025 (ending June 30, 2025) projects total revenues in a range of $3.075 billion +/- $150 million, with GAAP diluted EPS expected to be in a range of $8.28 +/- $0.781 and non-GAAP diluted EPS expected to be in a range of $8.53 +/- $0.78.
1. As of April 30, 2025, eBay Inc. reported Q1 2025 revenue of $2.6 billion, a 1% increase year-over-year on an as-reported basis and a 2% increase on an FX-neutral basis.
2.  eBay Inc. announced a Chief Financial Officer transition on April 30, 2025, with Steve Priest stepping down on May 11, 2025, and Peggy Alford taking over on May 12, 2025.
3.  The company projects Q2 2025 revenue between $2.59 and $2.66 billion, representing 0% to 2% year-over-year FX-neutral growth.
1. On April 24, 2025, Skyworks Solutions, Inc. changed its registered agent to Cogency Global Inc. and its registered office to 850 New Burton Road, Suite 201, Dover, DE 19904.
2. The company's fiscal year end is October 3.
3.  The 8-K filing indicates no amendments to previously filed submissions, no soliciting material, pre-commencement communications, or written communications.
1. Align Technology's Q1 2025 total revenues were $979.3 million, a 1.8% year-over-year decrease, negatively impacted by foreign exchange of approximately $31.1 million (3.1%).

2.  Q1 2025 Clear Aligner volume increased 6.2% year-over-year to 642,305 cases, while Clear Aligner revenue decreased 2.5% year-over-year to $796.8 million,  partially offset by unfavorable foreign exchange impacts of approximately $25.8 million (3.1%).

3.  Align Technology projects fiscal 2025 revenue growth to be in the range of 3.5% to 5.5% at current spot rates, with Clear Aligner volume growth expected to be in the mid-single digits,  but Clear Aligner ASPs are expected to decline year-over-year due to product mix shifts and emerging market dynamics; a potential additional U.S. tariff on goods from Mexico could also impact transfer prices.

1. Microsoft's fiscal Q3 2025 (ended March 31, 2025) results showed a 13% year-over-year revenue increase to $70.1 billion, a 16% increase in operating income to $32.0 billion, and an 18% increase in net income to $25.8 billion.
2.  Azure and other cloud services revenue grew by 33% year-over-year in constant currency during fiscal Q3 2025.

3. Microsoft's business outlook will be provided in a conference call and webcast on April 30, 2025, but the filing highlights numerous forward-looking risks, including intense competition, execution and competitive risks related to cloud-based and AI services, and legal and regulatory uncertainties.
1. VICI Properties' Q1 2025 net income decreased 9% year-over-year to $0.51 per share, primarily due to a CECL allowance change.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, VICI Properties held $3.2 billion in liquidity.
3. VICI Properties raised its full-year 2025 AFFO guidance to $2,470 million to $2,500 million (or $2.33 to $2.36 per diluted share), as of April 30, 2025.
1. Qualcomm's Q2 2025 revenue increased 17% year-over-year to $11 billion, with net income rising 21% to $2.8 billion, despite flat QTL revenue.
2. Apple's shift to its own modem chips is projected to substantially harm Qualcomm's QCT revenue, impacting future operating results and cash flow.
3. As of March 30, 2025, Qualcomm had $12.5 billion remaining in its stock repurchase program.
1. PPG Industries divested its remaining Russian operations in Q1 2025.
2. Net sales decreased by 4.3% year-over-year to $3,684 million in Q1 2025, while inventories increased by $269 million year-over-year.

3.  PPG expects $100 million in restructuring cash outlays in 2025, anticipating $75 million in savings;  $95 million in amortization expense for intangible assets is projected for the remaining nine months of 2025.
1. Vulcan Materials Company's total assets decreased by $392.7 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025, reaching $16,712.1 million.
2.  First-quarter 2025 net earnings increased 26% year-over-year to $128.9 million, or $0.97 per diluted share.
3. The company anticipates a $2.4 million pretax loss reclassification to interest expense by March 31, 2026.

1. Trane Technologies' Q1 2025 net revenues increased by 11.2% year-over-year to $4,688.5 million, but cash and cash equivalents significantly decreased to $860.5 million from $1,590.1 million at the end of 2024.
2. As of April 30, 2025, Trane Technologies had $5.8 billion remaining under its share repurchase authorizations.
3. The fair value of contingent consideration related to the Nuvolo acquisition was reduced to zero on April 4, 2025, due to unmet revenue targets.
1. PPL Corp's Q1 2025 net income increased by $107 million compared to Q1 2024, reaching $414 million.
2.  LG&E and KU have filed for $3.7 billion in capital expenditures from 2025-2031, but this is potentially threatened by the EPA's reconsideration of 31 environmental rules announced in March 2025.
3. PPL Corp has approximately $287 million in guarantees and indemnifications as of March 31, 2025,  with some considered reasonably possible but not probable of requiring payment.
1. Humana's net income for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, increased by 68.1% year-over-year to $1.2 billion.
2.  A "Value Creation Initiative" implemented by Humana resulted in $24 million in charges during the quarter ending March 31, 2025.
3.  Humana faces potential material adverse effects from an ongoing lawsuit regarding the RADV methodology.
1. Illinois Tool Works Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $3.8 billion, a 3.4% decrease year-over-year, with organic revenue down 1.6% (flat on an equal days’ basis).
2.  GAAP EPS for the first quarter of 2025 was $2.38, a 2% decrease year-over-year,  excluding a one-time inventory accounting change that benefited 2024's results.
3. The company maintained its full-year 2025 GAAP EPS guidance range of $10.15 to $10.55 per share, projecting revenue and organic growth of zero to two percent.
1. John Brase was promoted to President and Chief Operating Officer of J M Smucker Co., effective April 30, 2025, expanding his responsibilities to include certain external engagements.

2.  The Compensation Committee approved special equity awards totaling 57,000 restricted shares (35,000 to Brase and 22,000 to Marshall) with a five-year vesting period, 25% vesting annually starting after two years.

3. The J M Smucker Co. Board of Directors amended the company's Amended Regulations, removing the requirement that the President also be a director and updating shareholder meeting procedures as of April 30, 2025.
1. Steel Dynamics, Inc. declared a $0.50 per common share cash dividend on April 28, 2025, payable on or about July 11, 2025, to shareholders of record at the close of business on June 30, 2025.
2.  The company is investing in aluminum operations to diversify its product offerings, aiming to supply aluminum flat rolled products with high recycled content to various sectors.
3. No specific future impacts or risks with associated numbers were disclosed in this filing.
1. Christopher Schell, Intel's Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer, and General Manager of Sales, Marketing, and Communications, resigned on April 28, 2025, effective June 30, 2025.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, filed on April 30, 2025.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are quantified in this section of the filing.
1. PSEG's first-quarter 2025 GAAP net income increased by 11% year-over-year, exceeding the 9% increase in non-GAAP operating earnings.
2.  PSEG maintains its 2025 non-GAAP operating earnings guidance of $3.94-$4.06 per share.
3. PSEG projects that 90% of its earnings from 2025-2029 will come from its subsidiary, PSE&G.
1. PPL Corp's first-quarter 2025 ongoing earnings per share increased to $0.60, compared to $0.54 in the first quarter of 2024.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, PPL Corp reaffirmed its 2025 ongoing earnings forecast range of $1.75 to $1.87 per share and its 6% to 8% annual EPS and dividend growth targets through at least 2028.

3.  First-quarter 2025 reported earnings included $30 million in net special item after-tax charges primarily due to IT transformation, a Rhode Island Energy settlement, and acquisition integration expenses.
1. Western Digital Corp's fiscal third-quarter 2025 revenue was $2.29 billion, a 5% sequential decrease, primarily driven by lower unit shipments in the consumer and client segments.
2.  Year-over-year, Q3 2025 revenue increased 31% compared to Q3 2024,  with Cloud revenue up 38% due to increased bit shipments, despite a sequential decline.
3. Western Digital anticipates fiscal fourth-quarter 2025 revenue to be approximately $2.45 billion, with a non-GAAP EPS forecast of $1.45 +/- $0.20.
1. Builders FirstSource, Inc. released its 2025 Corporate Social Responsibility report on April 30, 2025, highlighting sustainability initiatives.
2.  The company achieved an industry-leading total recordable incident rate of 1.39 in 2024, a 10% year-over-year reduction.
3. In 2024, Builders FirstSource provided over $5 million in charitable giving to local communities.

1. Hess Corporation's first-quarter 2025 net income was $430 million ($1.39 per share), significantly lower than the $972 million ($3.16 per share) reported in the first quarter of 2024, primarily due to lower realized oil selling prices and sales volumes.
2.  The Yellowtail oil development in Guyana is on track to start up in the third quarter of 2025, with an initial gross production capacity of approximately 250,000 barrels of oil per day.
3. Hess Corporation anticipates full-year 2025 E&P capital and exploratory expenditures of approximately $4.5 billion.
1. Vulcan Materials Company's first-quarter 2025 Adjusted EBITDA increased by 27% year-over-year to $411 million, and its Adjusted EBITDA margin expanded by 420 basis points to 25.1%.

2.  As of April 30, 2025, Vulcan Materials Company's total debt to trailing-twelve months Adjusted EBITDA ratio was 2.3 times, or 2.2 times on a net debt basis, after using $400 million to redeem its 2025 notes.

3. The company expects to spend $750 to $800 million on maintenance and growth projects for the full year 2025, and anticipates Adjusted EBITDA of $2.35 to $2.55 billion, while acknowledging risks related to trade policy and interest rate uncertainty.
1. Yum! Brands reported first-quarter 2025 GAAP EPS of $0.90 and EPS excluding special items of $1.30, a 13% year-over-year increase.
2.  While worldwide system sales grew 5% (excluding foreign currency translation),  Pizza Hut Division system sales decreased by 4% year-over-year.
3. David Gibbs, Yum!'s CEO, announced his intention to retire in the first quarter of 2026.
1.  Garmin's Q1 2025 net sales increased 11% year-over-year to $1,535,099,000.
2.  As of March 29, 2025, 73% of Garmin's securities portfolio was at an unrealized loss.
3. Garmin has $209,805 remaining in its share repurchase program, expiring December 26, 2026.
1. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. reported a GAAP net loss of ($40.3) million for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, a $57.6 million decrease compared to the first quarter of 2024.

2.  Despite a ~3% decrease in total revenue year-over-year, primarily due to reduced Capacity Days and foreign exchange losses, the company exceeded its Adjusted EBITDA guidance for Q1 2025, reaching $453 million.

3. Full-year 2025 Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EPS guidance remains unchanged at approximately $2.72 billion and $2.05 respectively, despite downward revisions to Net Yield and Adjusted Net Cruise Cost Excluding Fuel guidance as of April 30, 2025.
1. Garmin Ltd. reported record first-quarter 2025 consolidated revenue of $1.54 billion, an 11% increase year-over-year.
2. The Outdoor segment experienced the most significant year-over-year revenue growth at 20%, driven by increased demand for adventure watches.
3.  Garmin Ltd. is maintaining its full-year 2025 pro forma EPS guidance of $7.80, despite updating its revenue expectations to approximately $6.85 billion, as of April 30, 2025.

1. Martin Marietta Materials, Inc. reported a significant year-over-year (YoY) decrease in earnings from operations, net earnings, and earnings per diluted share for the first quarter ended March 31, 2025, compared to the first quarter of 2024, despite increased revenues and gross profit.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Martin Marietta had $101 million of cash and cash equivalents and $1.2 billion of unused borrowing capacity.
3. Martin Marietta expects IIJA contributions to peak in 2026, followed by a typical tail thereafter, and anticipates that the successor bill to the IIJA may prioritize aggregates-intensive projects.
1. In the third quarter ended March 31, 2025, ADP's revenues increased 6% year-over-year to $5.6 billion, while net earnings and adjusted net earnings both increased 5% to $1.2 billion.
2.  ADP raised its full-year 2025 guidance for adjusted diluted EPS growth to 8-9% and adjusted EBIT margin expansion to 40-50 basis points as of April 30, 2025.

3. The interest on funds held for clients is projected to be $1.160 to $1.170 billion in fiscal year 2025, based on anticipated growth in client funds balances of 5% to 6% and an average yield increase to 3.1%.
1. Peter J. Hadley was appointed CFO of Automatic Data Processing, Inc., effective July 1, 2025, succeeding Don McGuire, who will remain in a transition role until September 30, 2025.
2. Mr. Hadley's total target equity award value for fiscal year 2026 is expected to be $4,875,000.

3.  Mr. Hadley's employment agreement includes an 18-month salary continuation upon involuntary termination without cause, a prorated bonus, and continued vesting in unvested equity awards for that period.
1. Caterpillar Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 sales dropped 10% year-over-year to $14.2 billion, primarily due to lower sales volume and unfavorable pricing.
2.  First-quarter 2025 profit per share significantly decreased to $4.20 from $5.75 in Q1 2024.
3.  Decreased sales volume, stemming from dealer inventory adjustments, negatively impacted future sales projections as of April 30, 2025.
1. GE HealthCare's Q1 2025 net income was $564 million, a 51% year-over-year increase.
2.  New US tariffs enacted in April 2025 are expected to negatively impact GE HealthCare's financials, though the extent remains uncertain.
3. GE HealthCare anticipates $40 million in restructuring expenses over the next year (ending March 31, 2026).
1. GE HealthCare announced a new $1 billion share repurchase program on April 30, 2025.
2. First-quarter 2025 EPS increased 51% year-over-year to $1.23, while free cash flow decreased 64% to $98 million.
3. Full-year 2025 adjusted EPS guidance was lowered to $3.90-$4.10, a 9-13% year-over-year decrease, partly due to $0.85 per share in tariffs.
1. Stanley Black & Decker's first-quarter 2025 revenue was $3.7 billion, a 3% decrease year-over-year, although organic growth was 1%, offset by currency and divestitures.

2.  First-quarter 2025 gross margin increased by 130 basis points year-over-year to 29.9%, primarily due to supply chain efficiencies and new product launches, partially offset by inflation and tariffs.
3.  Tariffs are projected to negatively impact 2025 EPS by approximately $0.75, net of price increases and supply chain adjustments planned for the next 12-24 months.
1. Humana revised its GAAP EPS guidance for fiscal year 2025 to approximately $14.68 from approximately $15.88, while affirming its Adjusted EPS guidance of approximately $16.25.
2.  Humana's first-quarter 2025 adjusted EPS of $11.58 exceeded expectations, primarily due to a shift in the timing of administrative expenses and investments, and CenterWell outperformance.

3. Humana anticipates a decline of approximately 550,000 individual Medicare Advantage members in 2025, resulting from exiting unprofitable plans and counties, but remains confident in its pricing strategy.

1. Generac Holdings Inc.'s Q1 2025 net sales increased 6% year-over-year to $942 million, driven by a 15% rise in residential product sales, while commercial and industrial product sales decreased by 5%.
2.  Adjusted net income attributable to the company in Q1 2025 was $75 million ($1.26 per share), compared to $53 million ($0.88 per share) in Q1 2024.

3.  Generac lowered its full-year 2025 net sales growth guidance to 0-7% (previously 3-7%) due to higher tariffs, uncertain government policies, and macroeconomic uncertainty;  the adjusted EBITDA margin guidance was also lowered to 17.0-19.0% (previously 18.0-19.0%).
1. Trane Technologies plc reported strong first-quarter 2025 results, with reported revenues up 11% year-over-year to $4.7 billion and adjusted continuing EPS up 26% to $2.45.

2.  The Americas segment significantly outperformed other segments, showing 14% year-over-year revenue growth (13% organic), compared to 4% growth in EMEA (6% organic) and a 4% decline in Asia Pacific (3% organic).

3.  Trane Technologies reaffirmed its full-year 2025 guidance, expecting revenue growth of approximately 7.5% to 8.5% and adjusted continuing EPS of $12.70 to $12.90,  and anticipates performing towards the high end of this range.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$666,820,338.78 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of April 29, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On April 29, 2025,  21,678,049 Class A shares and 10,699,797 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$666,820,338.78.
3. News Corp's future share repurchases are subject to market conditions, the market price of its stock, and other factors, and no ASX-listed CDIs will be repurchased in this program.

1. As of March 31, 2025, Edison International completed over 6,450 miles of covered conductor and over 2.5 million trims and removals in high fire-risk areas, resulting in zero ignitions from covered conductor failure.
2. Edison International projects a 6-8% compound annual growth rate in its rate base from 2023 to 2028.
3.  Edison International's April 29, 2025, business update highlighted significant risks related to wildfire liability, cybersecurity, and grid infrastructure upgrades.
1. Visa's operating expenses increased 22% year-over-year in the three months ended March 31, 2025, primarily due to a higher litigation provision.
2. Visa now has a $34.7 billion share repurchase program authorized as of April 30, 2025, with no expiration date.
3.  Visa's acquisition of Featurespace Limited in December 2024 cost $946 million, with $794 million allocated to goodwill.
1. Cadence Design Systems' revenue increased by $233.3 million (23%) year-over-year in the quarter ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Amortization expense for acquired intangibles is projected to be $68.3 million for the remainder of fiscal year 2025, based on forecasts made as of April 30, 2025.
3. Cadence is currently assessing the impact of two new accounting standards (ASU No. 2023-09 and ASU No. 2024-03) on its financial reporting.
1. Sysco's fiscal year 2025 net sales growth projection was lowered to approximately 3%, down from a previous projection of 4-5%, primarily due to lower than expected volume.
2. As of March 29, 2025, Sysco held $1.5 billion in cash and cash equivalents, but also faces a potential $131 million charge related to a tax law interpretation lawsuit.
3.  Sysco's Q3 2025 operating income and net earnings decreased by 5.7% and 5.6% respectively year-over-year, due to lower consumer confidence and adverse weather conditions.
1. Veralto Corp's net earnings increased by 22% in the three months ending April 4, 2025, compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  U.S. government tariffs pose a new risk factor, potentially increasing costs and reducing demand for Veralto's products.
3. Veralto Corp's total identifiable assets increased by $239 million between December 31, 2024, and April 4, 2025, reaching $6,645 million.
1. S&P Global Inc. will spin off its Mobility segment as a separate publicly traded company within the next 12-18 months.
2.  Q1 2025 revenue increased by 8% year-over-year to $3.777 billion.
3.  S&P Global Inc. faces ongoing legal proceedings in Australia with uncertain financial implications.
1. Booking Holdings' Q1 2025 net income decreased significantly to $333 million from $776 million in Q1 2024.

2.  Despite 7.2% year-over-year growth in total gross bookings,  Booking Holdings widened its full-year 2025 growth forecast range due to increased geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty (as of April 30, 2025).
3.  Booking.com's April 2025 bank guarantee arrangement related to a suspended Spanish fine presents a potential future financial risk.
